channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: World Briefing | Asia: India: 18 Die in Stampede in Mumbai
item.description: At least 18 people died early Saturday in a stampede as tens of thousands of members of a Muslim sect gathered to mourn the death of their spiritual leader in Mumbai.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing | Asia: Myanmar: Signs of Unrest Raise Alarms
item.description: The United States urged Myanmar to investigate reports that security forces and Buddhist mobs attacked members of the Rohingya Muslim minority, killing as many as 60 people.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing | Asia: Japan: Lawmaker Defends Shrine Visit
item.description: A top Japanese lawmaker on Friday denounced American criticism of Prime Minister Shinzo Abe’s visit last month to a Tokyo war shrine.
item.dc:creator: By MARTIN FACKLER

item.title: Obama Outlines Calibrated Curbs on Phone Spying
item.description: In a speech that seemed more calculated to reassure audiences at home and abroad than to force radical change, President Obama announced significant changes to the way the government collects and uses telephone records.
item.dc:creator: By MARK LANDLER and CHARLIE SAVAGE
item.media:description: President Obama set out his policies on surveillance by the government in a speech at the Justice Department on Friday.

item.title: World Briefing | Europe: Turkey: Contentious Medical Bill Signed
item.description: President Abdullah Gul signed a measure into law on Friday that makes it a crime to administer emergency first aid without government authorization.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: World Briefing | Africa: South Africa: Rhino Killings Increase
item.description: The South African government reported Friday that poachers killed 1,004 rhinos in South Africa last year, up from 668 in 2012.
item.dc:creator: By LOUIS LUCERO II

item.title: World Briefing | The Americas: Brazil: Lightning Damages Rio Statue
item.description: The famous statue of Christ overlooking Rio de Janeiro has been damaged during a storm. The right thumb was chipped, apparently by a lightning strike Thursday.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing | Middle East: Egypt: Clashes Erupt During Protests
item.description: Egypt’s security forces killed at least two protesters and arrested more than a hundred on Friday during demonstrations around the country.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK

item.title: In Keeping Grip on Data Pipeline, Obama Does Little to Reassure Industry
item.description: While President Obama bolstered some protections for citizens, he did nothing, at least yet, to address the data security concerns of U.S. technology companies.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID E. SANGER and CLAIRE CAIN MILLER
item.media:description: President Obama on Friday announced changes in a contentious surveillance program that has swept up many millions of records of Americans’ cellphone calls, though not their content.

item.title: Keeping Wide Net, Obama Sets Limits on Phone Spying
item.description: President Obama, responding on Friday to months of debate set off by the disclosures of Edward J. Snowden, said he would require intelligence agencies to get court permission before tapping into a vast trove of phone data.
item.dc:creator: By MARK LANDLER and CHARLIE SAVAGE
item.media:description: In the front row at Mr. Obama's speech were his top security officials, from left to right: F.B.I. Director James B. Comey, C.I.A. Director John Brennan, Director of National Intelligence James Clapper and Homeland Security Secretary Jeh C. Johnson.

item.title: 384 Priests Defrocked Over Abuse in 2 Years
item.description: After the child sexual abuse scandal exploded in Europe and beyond, the Vatican defrocked 260 priests in 2011 and 124 more in 2012, according to statistics compiled by The Associated Press.
item.dc:creator: By LAURIE GOODSTEIN

item.title: Bill With Antigay Provisions Is Blocked by Ugandan Leader
item.description: President Yoweri Museveni was in an uncomfortable position as Western governments that provide aid condemned the bill’s harsh sentences.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By NICHOLAS KULISH

item.title: Last-Ditch Effort Emerges to Restore Order in Central African Republic
item.description: An unlikely experiment is underway in the Central African Republic as a council of 135 rebels, rivals, politicians and others is trying to choose an interim president.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: By ADAM NOSSITER
item.media:description: People fled the violence in the Central African Republic this week on a truck headed to Chad. Nearly a million people have left their homes in the republic.

item.title: Sanctions Eased, Iran Gets Feelers From Old Trading Partners
item.description: Potential investors from Europe are making visits to meet with Iranian officials, but no one seems near to sealing a deal.
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS ERDBRINK

item.title: Papua New Guinea, Where Violence Can Seem Like the Norm for Women
item.description: The Australian government found that nearly every woman has experienced some form of physical violence, sexual violence or both.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: Taliban Attack Kills 16 at Restaurant Favored by Westerners
item.description: The Taliban claimed responsibility for an attack in which a suicide bomber cleared a path for two gunmen, who ran in and fired on diners.
item.dc:creator: By MATTHEW ROSENBERG
item.media:description: Afghan security forces helped a man wounded Friday in an attack on Taverna du Liban, a Kabul restaurant. Many embassies are in the neighborhood.

item.title: The Lede: Twitter Suspends Hamas Accounts
item.description: The accounts were used by the militant wing of the Palestinian government to directly communicate with the Israel Defense Forces during at 2012 bombing campaign.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY
item.media:description: A screenshot of an exchange between an Israeli military spokesman and the military wing of Hamas on Twitter in October.

item.title: The Lede: Al Jazeera Denies That Journalists Detained in Egypt Confessed to Terror Charges
item.description: Egypt said journalists from Al Jazeera English detained on Dec. 29 had “confessed” to being members of the Muslim Brotherhood, but their network denied the claim.
item.dc:creator: By LIAM STACK

item.title: News Analysis: A Crucial Caveat in Obama’s Vow on Phone Data
item.description: President Obama left the “end” of the bulk telephone data program to another day in a speech partly intended to convince the public that spy programs are being run appropriately.
item.dc:creator: By PETER BAKER

item.title: Gays Can Be ‘Relaxed and Calm’ at the Olympics, Putin Says
item.description: President Vladimir V. Putin said visitors to Sochi for the Olympic Games, including gay men and lesbians, could be “relaxed and calm,” but he defended a ban on “homosexual propaganda.”
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW ROTH
item.media:credit: Alexey Nikolsky/RIA Novosti Kremlin, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia said on Friday that no one would be targeted at the Games under a federal law banning “homosexual propaganda” among minors.

item.title: A Top U.N. Rights Official Describes ‘Horror’ in South Sudan
item.description: At the end of a four-day visit, a human rights official said “mass atrocities” had been committed, with reports of killings and sexual violence.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: By SOMINI SENGUPTA

item.title: Blast at Antigovernment March Raises Tensions in Bangkok
item.description: The attack intensified tensions in the city as a dwindling but dedicated core of protesters continues to block access to a number of major intersections and government buildings.
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS FULLER
item.media:description: Protesters were given first aid after an attack, most likely with a grenade.

item.title: Syria Proposes Aleppo Cease-Fire as Opposition Weighs Attending Peace Talks
item.description: The proposal appeared to be an effort by the government to show good faith before a peace conference next week aimed at ending Syria’s civil war.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
National Coalition of Syrian Revolutionary and Opposition Forces
item.dc:creator: By BEN HUBBARD
item.media:description: Mr. Moallem, left, said Mr. Lavrov, right, would make the contacts necessary to “establish a zero hour for a cease-fire and the cessation of military operations” in Aleppo, Syria’s largest city.

item.title: Wife of Indian Minister Found Dead in Hotel Room After Twitter Row
item.description: - The wife of an Indian government minister was found dead in a New Delhi hotel room on Friday, police said, days after she was involved in a row with a Pakistani woman journalist over Twitter.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: Britain Scrambles to Fill Skills Gap
item.description: Faced with a shortage of skilled manufacturing workers, the government and industry are behind a push to get teenagers into apprenticeships.
item.dc:creator: By KIMIKO DE FREYTAS-TAMURA
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Six years ago Liam Brooker started working as an apprentice at Brompton Bicycles, a London maker of foldable bicycles. Now he is the company's star at welding.
